Further note, this is required for strong typing and further TSification of the `browser` code in particular things like the `navigation-controller`
**No Release Notes**

The `converter` here can be typed as `string` and `T`.

```suggestion
  name: string, defaultValue: T, converter: (value: string) => T = value => value
```

Then `parseOption` is strongly typed
This concerns me, why are we having to redeclare node globals, shouldn't they be coming through from `@types/node`

Ah, I can answer that! `@types/node` has those defined as _actual_ globals.

Not defined:
```
global.__dirname
```

Defined:
```
__dirname
```
Upon closer investigation, that doesn't work – and it makes sense, this here doesn't work: `(value: string) => T = value => value`
The two failures are unrelated :v:

TypeScript will associate these comments with the function if using the Docs style comments (e.g. `/** comment */`).
https://typedoc.org/guides/doccomments/
That's actually on purpose – one shouldn't mistake the link for the _actual_ implementation, but it's a useful guide for developers coming in and working with this code.
